title: Oadby
text:
Oadby is a town in the borough of <a href="Oadby%20and%20Wigston">Oadby and Wigston</a> in the county of Leicestershire, England. Oadby is a district centre south east of <a href="Leicester">Leicester</a> city centre on the <a href="A6%20road%20%28England%29">A6</a> trunk road. <a href="Leicester%20Racecourse">Leicester Racecourse</a> is situated on the border between Oadby and <a href="Stoneygate">Stoneygate</a>. The <a href="University%20of%20Leicester">University of Leicester</a> Botanical Garden is in Oadby. Oadby had a population of 23,849 in 2011 and like its neighbour <a href="Wigston">Wigston</a>, Oadby is made up of five wards. The Borough of Oadby and Wigston is twinned with <a href="Maromme">Maromme</a> in France, and <a href="Norderstedt">Norderstedt</a> in Germany.
History.
Angles, Danes and Normans.
There has been a habitation in Oadby since an <a href="Angles">Anglian</a> settlement in the early Anglo-Saxon period. Though the name Oadby is Danish (meaning "Outi's dwelling") it must have existed long before the Danish invasions as is shown by the existence of a pagan Anglian cemetery. The original Anglian name has been lost. In 1760, on Brocks Hill, evidence of an Anglian burial ground was discovered. The <a href="Middle%20Angles">Middle Angles</a> came under the rule of the kings of <a href="Mercia">Mercia</a> and were later conquered by the Danish invaders. Oadby is one of seventy <a href="Danes%20%28Germanic%20tribe%29">Danish</a> settlements in <a href="Leicestershire">Leicestershire</a> ending with "-by", which means <a href="village">village</a> or settlement. Its name probably came from <a href="Old%20Norse">Old Norse</a> "Auðarbýr" = "Auði's settlement". Danish rule continued until 920, when <a href="List%20of%20English%20monarchs">King</a> <a href="Alfred%20the%20Great">Alfred the Great</a> won his battles against the Danes: the Oadby area is supposed to be the site of at least one of these battles.
In the <a href="Domesday%20Book">Domesday Book</a>, 1086, Oadby's name was recorded as Oldebi. Other early forms are Oladebi, Outheby (Feet of Fines, 1199), Onderby and, finally, Oadby. When <a href="List%20of%20English%20monarchs">King</a> <a href="Harold%20II%20of%20England">Harold</a> had been defeated, <a href="William%20the%20Conqueror">William the Conqueror</a> gave Oadby to <a href="Hugh%20de%20Grandmesnil">Hugh de Grandmesnil</a>, Governor of Leicestershire, who founded the parish church of Oadby on the site of the present St Peter's Church. The tenants of the manor of Oadby were Roger who held one and half carucates, and Countess Judith who held 9 carucates and 2 bovates, and 30 acres of meadow. On the Countess's land were 46 socmen, 11 bordars and 3 serfs; 2 carucates were let to Robert de Buci. The manor was held in 1444 by William Ferrers; in 1457 it was held by William Grey, Lord Ferrers of Groby. In 1541 the manor was held by John Waldron; his successor John Waldron sold it in 1629 to Sir John Lombe. In 1831 the main landed proprietors were the trustees of the late George Wyndham (patrons of the vicarage), George Legh Keck (lord of the manor) and Thomas Pares.
Modern times.
Oadby remained a small settlement until the late 19th century when it became a fashionable suburb for the businessmen of Leicester, such as the factory-owners of <a href="Leicester">Leicester</a>'s shoe and stocking manufacturers. Many substantial houses were built in Oadby, some of which are now used by the <a href="University%20of%20Leicester">University of Leicester</a>.
Stoughton Road in Oadby contains 2 sets of houses of historical interest. Some of the Framework Knitters Homes date back to 1909, while the North Memorial Homes, financed by Sir Jonathan North (former Mayor of Leicester) were built in 1927 and opened in the same year by the <a href="Edward%20VIII%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Prince of Wales</a>. As well as a series of houses, the North Memorial Homes site also houses the North Memorial Hall, built in a neo-Georgian style, which has been leased to Oadby Evangelical Free Church since 1974.
Expansion of Oadby took place rapidly in the 20th century and was still continuing in 2017. Many residential developments have been constructed meaning the population in 2011 reached 23,849.
Oadby today.
Oadby is a large district centre with a good range of shops,
services and facilities which are mostly located along The Parade. It is predominantly a residential area for families. 
Oadby has a diverse population, by age, country of origin and religion. In the region of 20% of the population is under 17 years, 21% over 65 years, 17% were born outside the British Isles and 22%-29% (depending on source) come from <a href="Classification%20of%20ethnicity%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">ethnically</a> diverse communities.
The town has a mixture of properties, including Edwardian houses, new purpose-built accommodation blocks, three major supermarkets and restaurants across all price points. Oadby Student Village is situated in the north-east of the town, including residences for the local university students. 
Oadby Industrial Estate, situated to the south-west of the town, contains a large number of small and medium-sized businesses.
Notable local parks include Coombe Park, Rosemead Park, Uplands Park and Brockshill Country Park.
Sport and culture.
The local football club, <a href="GNG%20Oadby%20Town%20F.C.">GNG Oadby Town F.C.</a>, play in the <a href="United%20Counties%20League">United Counties League</a>. <a href="Leicester%20Tigers">Leicester Tigers</a>, the premiership <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> club, train at their centre at Oval Park on Wigston Road, Oadby.
Oadby's other local football club is Oadby Owls F.C., who cater for many ages up to under-18s. They play at the municipal Coombe Park and are a very popular football club in Leicester. The club is known to be very successful around the Leicestershire area.
Oadby's Parklands Leisure Centre is home to the <a href="Dolly%20Rockit%20Rollers">Dolly Rockit Rollers</a> <a href="roller%20derby">roller derby</a> league. Members of the <a href="UKRDA">UKRDA</a>, they were ranked amongst the top eight teams in the country in 2011.
The local tennis club (Oadby Granville Tennis Club) is situated on London Road and caters for all standards of tennis and ages and has produced county players and county champions amongst past members.
Education.
Oadby is the home of <a href="Beauchamp%20College">Beauchamp College</a> (formerly Kibworth Beauchamp Grammar School) and <a href="Gartree%20High%20School">Gartree High School</a>, both of which were attended by <a href="John%20Deacon">John Deacon</a> of <a href="Queen%20%28band%29">Queen</a>. The <a href="University%20of%20Leicester">University of Leicester</a> has its halls of residence in the northern part of the town.
Transport.
The main <a href="A6%20road%20%28England%29">A6</a> dual carriageway passes through the town, bypassing the commercial centre. The <a href="A563%20road">A563</a> Leicester Ring Road intersects with the <a href="A6%20road%20%28England%29">A6</a> close to Leicester Race Course to the north of Oadby town centre.
Rail.
The nearest railway stations are <a href="Leicester%20railway%20station">Leicester</a> and <a href="South%20Wigston%20railway%20station">South Wigston</a> both less than away.
Bus.
Oadby and the surrounding areas are served by <a href="Arriva%20Fox%20County">Arriva Midlands</a> route 31 which operates a loop around the housing estates, Arriva X3 and <a href="Stagecoach%20Midlands">Stagecoach Gold</a> X7 both serving nearby villages including <a href="Kibworth">Kibworth</a> and <a href="Market%20Harborough">Market Harborough</a>.
<a href="Centrebus">Centrebus</a> operate service 40 Circle Line which links Oadby to nearby <a href="Wigston%20Magna">Wigston</a> and <a href="Leicester%20General%20Hospital">General Hospital</a>.
